system: You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
response: Ġ (minuscule: ġ) is a letter of the Latin script, formed from G with the addition of a dot above the letter. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A0)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
response: Ġ is used in some Arabic transliteration schemes, such as DIN 31635 and ISO 233, to represent the letter غ (ġayn).In the Standard Tunisian Alphabet Ġ is used in Tunisian Arabic to represent the voiced pharyngeal fricative /ʕ/. Whereas it uses Ğ to represent the voiced uvular fricative /ʁ/. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A0)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
response: Ġ is used in the romanization of Classical or Eastern Armenian to represent the letter Ղ/ղ (ġat). <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A0)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
response: Ġ is present in the Chechen Latin alphabet, created in the 1990s. The Cyrillic equivalent is гI, which represents the sound /ɣ/. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A0)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
response: In some dialects of the Iñupiaq language, an Eskaleut language, Ġ is used to represent the voiced uvular fricative /ʁ/. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A0)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
response: Ġ was formerly used in Irish to represent the lenited form of G. The digraph gh is now used. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A0)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
response: Ġ is the 7th letter of the Maltese alphabet, preceded by F and followed by G. It represents the voiced postalveolar affricate [dʒ]. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A0)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
response: ⟨ġ⟩ is sometimes (about 16th century) used to represent real [g], to distinguish it from the letter ⟨g⟩, which represented the consonant [j]. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A0)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
response: ⟨Ġ⟩ is sometimes used in modern scholarly transcripts of Old English to represent [j] or [dʒ] (after ⟨n⟩), to distinguish it from ⟨g⟩ pronounced as /ɣ/, which is otherwise spelled identically. The digraph ⟨cg⟩ was also used to represent [dʒ]. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A0)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
response: ⟨Ġ⟩ is used in some Ukrainian transliteration schemes, mainly ISO 9:1995, as the letter Ґ. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A0)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
response: ⟨ġ⟩ is sometimes used as a phonetic symbol transcribing [ɣ] or [ŋ]. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A0)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
response: Ġ is used in the transliteration of Georgian to represent the letter ღ. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A0)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ġ.
response: ISO 8859-3 (Latin-3) includes Ġ at D5 and ġ at F5 for use in Maltese, and ISO 8859-14 (Latin-8) includes Ġ at B2 and ġ at B3 for use in Irish. Precomposed characters for Ġ and ġ have been present in Unicode since version 1.0. As part of WGL4, it can be expected to display correctly on most computer systems. OpenAI's GPT-2 uses U+0120 (Ġ) as a substitute for the space character in its tokens. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A0)
